bibl.title: Letter from Felipe Ponce Carbonell to Philip Showalter Hench, [1952]

div1.p: Carbonell informs Hench that, largely through the efforts of Colete, the Cuban government has approved $50,000 for the preservation of Camp Lazear. However, he is unsure how the money will be used.

div1.head: Letter from Felipe Ponce Carbonell to Philip Showalter Hench, [1952]
div1.opener:
REPUBLICA DE CUBA
----
CLINICA DE MATERNIDAD OBRERA
DE LA PROVINCIA DE LA HABANA
-------
MARIANAO
----
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic.
Rochester. Minn.
My Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I received your letter on March 28 and didn't answered it
right away because Mr. Honorato Colete and I were waiting for the
result of what the Minister of Public Works had offered to Mr. Colete.

I was at the city of Camagüey when I read in the Diario de la Marin
(a newspaper) the pleasant new, that the Council of Ministers had
aproved the measure of voting a credit of $5o.ooo to “presrve” the case-
ta. I am still wondering about the meaning of the word “preserve”. I
hope that as soon as Colete and I can see the Minister, we will find out
if it means that that money will be spentt in preserving the caseta from
a wreck or, what I believe, that a monument is going to be built with
that money.

As soon as I arrived to Havana I phoned to Colete and we
decided to send a cablegram to you with the good new of the credit of
$50.000, and Colete was in charge of sending it, with our both signatu
res.

This morning I received your telegram addresed to me but that undou
btedly is for we both. I don't want to miss the oportunity of telling
you, that the money was obtained due to the enthusiam that Colete
is displaying near the Minister.

I hope to, see Colete this afternoon and then we will write
together a letter to you with more details.

With my best regards for Mrs. Hench and your
children I am
div1.closer:
sincerely yours Dr. Felipe Carbonell Colete's addres is Mr. Honorato Colete
Habana 254
Havana.
